item.title: Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom - Best Recipes For Heat Resistance
item.description:
Highlights

  • Heat-resistant gear in Tears of the Kingdom can be costly, but cooking up certain dishes can provide high-level heat resistance for over 10 minutes.
  • Recipes like Chilly Mushroom Skewer are easy ways to boost heat resistance, ideal for exploring arid regions without being affected.
  • Players can find ingredients like Hylian Tomatoes and Chillshrooms in various regions of Hyrule to create meals with high-level heat resistance.

Tears of the Kingdom features a few regions with some pretty extreme heat, and without proper gear, players may find themselves struggling to survive. Heat-resistant gear can be pretty pricey, and Tears of the Kingdom players can often find themselves struggling to make enough rupees to afford such a big purchase.

Luckily, there are other ways to gain heat resistance. By cooking up certain dishes, players can gain enough heat resistance to survive in some of the game's hottest regions. Here, players can find some of the best recipes for heat resistance in Tears of the Kingdom .

Updated August 9, 2024, by Ashely Claudino: To improve this list, we've added a table that summarizes each recipe at the end of the article. This way, gamers can easily decide which recipe is more practical for them to craft.

12 Chilly Cheesy Baked Fish

A Heat-Resistant Seafood Delight

  • Chilly Cheese Baked Fish recipe: 1 Hateno Cheese, 4 Chillfin Trouts

One simple recipe players can cook to give Link some Heat Resistance is Chilly Cheesy Baked Fish . This recipe will restore plenty of Hearts, as well as provide Link with high-level heat resistance for over ten minutes.

Players will need some Hateno Cheese and one to four Chillfin Trouts. The more trouts the player uses, the more heat resistance they will gain. Chillfin Trout can be found in colder water - in areas such as Hebra and Zora's Domain .

11 Chilly Elixir

A Useful Light Potion

  • Chilly Elixir recipe : 1 Cold Darner, Monster Parts
  • Alternative Chilly Elixir recipe: 1 Winterwing Butterfly, Monster Parts

Sometimes Tears of the Kingdom players may find that they're running low on ingredients to use for meals. In this case, they can use their spare monster parts to create elixirs. These won't restore Hearts, but they can provide Link with some helpful buffs. In this case, a Chilly Elixir can be made to increase Link's heat resistance . If done right, the player can get high-level heat resistance for over ten minutes.

For this recipe, players will need at least one Cold Darner or Winterwing Butterfly, and some monster parts. The more valuable the monster part, the longer the elixir will last. Insects can be quite tricky to catch in Tears of the Kingdom , so players are better off buying them from Beedle.

10 Chilly Seafood Rice Balls

Typical Hylian Rice Ball Recipe

  • Chilly Seafood Rice Balls recipe: 1 Hylian Rice, 1-4 Chillfin Trouts

The Chilly Seafood Rice Balls recipe in Tears of the Kingdom can be a great way to provide Link with some extra heat resistance. The recipe itself is pretty simple to make. Players will need some Hylian Rice and one to four Chillfin Trouts.

Players who need a bit of extra heat resistance should try to use as many Chillfin Trouts as possible . If the player doesn't need the bonus for long, they can probably just stick to using one or two fish instead.

9 Chilly Tomato Seafood Soup

Combat the Heat with a Chilly Soup

  • Chilly Tomato Seafood Soup recipe: 1 Hylian Tomato, 1-4 Chillfin Trouts

Hylian Tomatoes are one of the most common ingredients players can find in Tears of the Kingdom . Luckily, there are plenty of great recipes that can be cooked using them, including Tomato Seafood Soup. This variation on the recipe will help boost Link's heat resistance.

The player will need one Hylian Tomato, and one to four Chillfin Trouts. This will provide Link with high-level heat resistance for over ten minutes, making it a great meal to pack if the player is planning on exploring the Gerudo Desert.

8 Chilly Herb Sauté

Refresh Yourself with a Herb Sauté

  • Chilly Herb Sauté recipe: 1Goron Spice, 1-4 Cool Safflinas

To cook Chilly Herb Sauté, players will need to make sure they have between one and four Cool Safflinas and some Goron Spice. This dish will provide the player with some low-level heat resistance , which should be enough to survive some of the tamer warm regions in the game.

Cool Safflinas can be found in some of Hyrule's more elevated regions, including the Hebra Mountains or Gerudo Highlands. As for Goron Spice, this can be purchased in Goron City by visiting the General Store there.

7 Chilly Fruit Pie

Fresh Fruit to Bring Down Body Temperature

  • Chilly Fruit Pie recipe: 1 Goat Butter, 1 Tabantha Wheat, 1 Cane Sugar, 1-2 Hydromelons

Players who would prefer to give TOTK 's Link a sweet treat can prepare some Chilly Fruit Pie. This recipe is excellent for adding some heat resistance, but it does require quite a few different ingredients. Players will need to make sure they have some Goat Butter, Tabantha Wheat, Cane Sugar, and one or two Hydromelons.

Hydromelons can be bought in Gerudo Town or found growing around the Gerudo Desert. Goat Butter, Tabantha Wheat, and Cane Sugar can all be bought from various merchants around Hyrule.

6 Chilly Mushroom Risotto

A Creamy Meal to Chill You Out

  • Chilly Mushroom Risotto recipe: 1 Goat Butter, 1 Hylian Rice, 1 Rock Salt, 1-2 Chillshrooms

This fun recipe requires quite a considerable number of ingredients. Players will need Rock Salt, Goat Butter, Hylian Rice, and either one or two Chillshrooms. The quantity of Chillshrooms the player uses will directly impact the amount of Heat Resistance the dish will provide .

Rock Salt is commonly found while mining or can be purchased from various merchants. Obtaining Goat Butter can be done for free by visiting the spa in Gerudo Town, where players can find some lying around. It can also be bought from multiple merchants, as can Hylian Rice. Finally, Chillshrooms can be found in colder regions of Hyrule, such as the Hebra Mountains.

5 Chilly Tomato Mushroom Stew

A Healthy Meal with High-Level Heat Resistance

  • Chilly Tomato Mushroom Stew recipe: 1 Hylian Tomato, 1-4 Chillshrooms

Players who are looking to get better heat resistance in Tears of the Kingdom should try making some Chilly Tomato Mushroom Stew. This recipe is especially great for players who have too many Hylian Tomatoes. To make it, they will need between one and four Chillshrooms and a Hylian Tomato.

This dish will then offer some high-level heat resistance for ten and a half minutes , perfect for when Link is trying to get through the Gerudo Desert. Players who haven't come across any Hylian Tomatoes yet can find them all over Hyrule, most commonly in TOTK 's East and West Necluda.

4 Chilly Mushroom Rice Balls

Long-Lasting Chill Effect

  • Chilly Mushroom Rice Balls recipe: 1 Hylian Rice, 1-4 Chillshrooms

Creating some Chilly Mushroom Rice Balls is pretty simple for players. All they need is some Hylian Rice and one to four Chillshrooms. The more Chillshrooms they use, the greater heat resistance they will receive .

Hylian Rice can be obtained from various vendors scattered throughout Hyrule or occasionally found while chopping grass. On the other hand, Chillshrooms are commonly found in TOTK 's colder regions, such as the Gerudo Highlands or Hebra Mountains, typically growing at the base of pine trees.

3 Chilly Fragrant Mushroom Sauté

A Mouth-Watering, Chilly Dish

  • Chilly Fragrant Mushroom Sauté recipe: 1 Goron Spice, 1-4 Chillshrooms

To prepare Chilly Fragrant Mushroom Sauté, players will need to collect between one and four Chillshrooms, as well as some Goron Spice. This awesome dish is one of the best in Tears of the Kingdom for its ability to enhance the player's heat resistance, providing high-level heat resistance for eleven and a half minutes .

For players seeking Chillshrooms, these mushrooms can be found quite commonly in the colder regions of Hyrule. As for acquiring Goron Spice, it can be conveniently purchased from the General Store located in Goron City.

2 Chilly Fruit and Mushroom Mix

Chilly Meal With a Flexible Ingredient Choice

  • Chilly Fruit and Mushroom Mix recipe: 1-4 Chillshrooms
  • Alternative Chilly Fruit and Mushroom Mix recipe: 1-4 Hydromelons

The Chilly Fruit and Mushroom Mix recipe gives players a bit more flexibility with their ingredients. They will need to combine some Chillshrooms and Hydromelons, but they can use whatever proportion of each that they wish. For example, if the player has more Chillshrooms to spare than Hydromelons, they could use four of the former and one of the latter, or vice versa.

Hydromelons can be purchased in Gerudo Town, or found growing around the Gerudo Desert. Chillsrooms, on the other hand, can be found in the colder regions of Hyrule, such as the Gerudo Highlands or Hebra Mountains.

1 Chilly Mushroom Skewer

Nothing Like Some Chillshrooms to Combat the Heat

  • Chilly Mushroom Skewer recipe: 2-5 Chillshrooms

Cooking a Chilly Mushroom Skewer is one of the easiest methods for players to boost their heat resistance in Tears of the Kingdom . This recipe is incredibly straightforward, as it only requires players to cook up to five Chillshrooms.

This dish will provide players with the maximum heat resistance buff, with high-level heat resistance for twelve and a half minutes . This makes the Chilly Mushroom Skewer ideal for players who aim to explore the more arid regions of TOTK 's Hyrule without being affected by the heat.

List of the Best Heat-Resistant Meals in Tears of the Kingdom

Here are the meals mentioned in this article and their respective recipes to make it easier for fans to decide what they're going to cook:

Recipe

Ingredients

Chilly Cheesy Baked Fish

  • 1 Hateno Cheese
  • 4 Chillfin Trouts

Chilly Elixir

  • 1 Cold Darner
  • Monster Parts

or

  • 1 Winterwing Butterfly
  • Monster Parts

Chilly Seafood Rice Balls

  • 1 Hylian Rice
  • 1-4 Chillfin Trouts

Chilly Tomato Seafood Soup

  • 1 Hylian Tomato
  • 1-4 Chillfin Trouts

Chilly Herb Sauté

  • 1 Goron Spice
  • 1-4 Cool Safflinas

Chilly Fruit Pie

  • 1 Goat Butter
  • 1 Tabantha Wheat
  • 1 Cane Sugar
  • 1-2 Hydromelons

Chilly Mushroom Risotto

  • 1 Goat Butter
  • 1 Hylian Rice
  • 1 Rock Salt
  • 1-2 Chillshrooms

Chilly Tomato Mushroom Stew

  • 1 Hylian Tomato
  • 1-4 Chillshrooms

Chilly Mushroom Rice Balls

  • 1 Hylian Rice
  • 1-4 Chillshrooms

Chilly Fragrant Mushroom Sauté

  • 1 Goron Spice
  • 1-4 Chillshrooms

Chilly Fruit and Mushroom Mix

  • 1-4 Chillshrooms

or

  • 1-4 Hydromelons

Chilly Mushroom Skewer

  • 2-5 Chillshrooms

item.title: Why Riot Games' Canceled Fighting Game Probably Had Little to Do With MultiVersus
item.description:
Highlights

  • Development of Riot Games' canceled fighting game Pool Party faced internal challenges and transitioned from a competitive to a party game.
  • MultiVersus' performance issues, including backlash over microtransactions and balancing, likely did not influence Pool Party's cancelation.
  • The termination of Pool Party may be linked to the prioritization of Riot Games' upcoming 2XKO, a 2v2 team-based fighting game currently in alpha testing.

Riot Games has a strong history of developing successful games, including League of Legends , Teamfight Tactics , and Valorant . As the developer continues to expand its portfolio, especially within the League of Legends universe, Riot Games' current and future projects are well worth keeping an eye on. Unfortunately, despite its numerous successes, not all of its endeavors have been fruitful.

Strikingly, development on Riot Games' Smash Bros .-inspired platform fighting game, codenamed Pool Party , was halted in July. Although the game was never officially announced, reports suggest that it would have featured characters from the studio's extensive roster competing against one another. This may have included a clash of iconic figures from across the developer's universe, such as Valorant agents and champions from League of Legends and Arcane . Though there is speculation linking Pool Party 's cancelation to MultiVersus ' performance, it's unlikely that the two events are meaningfully connected.

Riot Games' Pool Party Went Through Several Changes Before Its Cancelation

MultiVersus' Poor Performance Was Likely Unrelated to Riot's Decision

According to Mikhail Klimentov of The Washington Post, Pool Party encountered numerous internal challenges during its production process. Although the project's timeline was never publicly revealed, the fighting game, intended to be set within the League of Legends franchise, was originally intended to be highly competitive before transitioning into a party game. While MultiVersus does offer a competitive aspect with its Ranked Mode, which features five divisions, several players, according to Steam reviews, find the game more enjoyable when played casually or with friends.

Additionally, MultiVersus faced challenges following its relaunch, including backlash over microtransactions and balancing issues. Given the substantial overlap in recognizable characters between Riot Games and Warner Bros. Interactive, it appears Riot Games recognized that a strong roster alone wouldn't guarantee the game's success. However, to claim that MultiVersus ' troubled history played a major part in Pool Party 's eventual cancelation is doubtful, even though long-term success is rare for platformer fighting games outside senior series such as Super Smash Bros.

To claim that MultiVersus ' troubled history played a major part in Pool Party 's eventual cancelation is doubtful.

Riot Games' Canceled Fighting Game Makes 2XKO a Priority, For Better or For Worse

The termination of Pool Party was met with frustration from both developers and fans. Insiders claim that roughly 70–80 developers were removed or reassigned from the project. While Joe Hixson, the Leading Corp Comms for Riot Games, explained that game development involves constant experimentation and project iteration, the cancelation of the fighting game remains a disappointment for both the development team and its community.

Notably, the cancelation of Pool Party appears more likely linked to the progression of 2XKO , Riot Games' League of Legends 2v2 team-based fighting game. Currently in Alpha Lab testing from August 8 to 19, the title is poised for a 2025 release after nearly a decade of investment. Announced in 2019 under the name Project L , it appears to have experienced a challenging production process. Due to the significant amount of time and resources put towards the upcoming title, 2XKO now faces considerable pressure as the sole fighting game currently in active development by the company.

It is odd that Riot Games was simultaneously developing two fighting game projects. While such a venture could be seen as an ambitious exploration of the genre, it also raises questions about resource allocation and strategic focus. The unexpected cancelation of Pool Party has undoubtedly left a void for fans eager to see their favorite characters cross-over within the Riot Games universe. Fortunately, League of Legends fans and fighting game enthusiasts can still look forward to the upcoming release of 2XKO .

item.title: The Best Games On Xbox Game Pass (August 2024)
item.description:
Microsoft’s Game Pass service is easily worth the price of admission. Many might balk at the concept of having their video game library locked behind a subscription service, but the fact is subscribers get access to an incredible selection of titles spanning from indie darlings to triple-A blockbusters for a surprisingly affordable monthly fee.

With such a dizzying array of fantastic titles on display, it can be a daunting task deciding which ones are worth a player’s time. Given that the cost of entry is taken care of with the subscription fee, the most pressing matter is determining the best use of your hard drive space. Thankfully, the diamonds of this collection are readily apparent. Here’s a look at the greatest games that Xbox Game Pass has to offer.

Don't yet have Xbox Game Pass?

Click here to join Xbox Game Pass and get your first month for $1.

The selections listed here will include games available on EA Play, which is included with a subscription to Game Pass Ultimate.

Halo: The Master Chief Collection

The adventures of the Master Chief have never been as accessible as they are in the Master Chief Collection . This gathering of Halo games is the definitive collection of 343 Industries’ endeavors to immortalize the series. Not only is every mainline Halo game (not counting Halo 5: Guardians ) included, but the fantastic Halo 3: ODST and Halo: Reach were added as well.

From beloved campaign co-op to thrilling Firefight matches to iconic multiplayer modes, the Master Chief Collection has it all. Anyone who thinks of themselves as a Halo fan should consider it a must-play from Xbox Game Pass. And for those who have never completed the Master Chief’s saga, there is no better way to finish the fight.

Crash Bandicoot N. Sane Trilogy

With Microsoft’s acquisition of companies like Activision and Blizzard, we’re just beginning to see popular titles from these publishers make their way to Xbox Game Pass. And while getting Modern Warfare III on the service has been all well and good, nothing oozes such volatile levels of excitement the way Crash Bandicoot does. So thanks to the addition of the N. Sane Trilogy to Game Pass’ library, that excitement is ready to hop, spin, and dash its way into our hearts.

This trilogy of remastered platforming classics is the way to play through the nostalgia. Complete with the first game, Cortex Strikes Back , and Warped , this collection of Crash games has it all. If you’re fond of the platformers of yesteryear, not only are you among friends, you’re also in for a treat once you download and play the N. Sane Trilogy .

Valorant

Put Counter-Strike into a box with Overwatch then spend a few minutes shaking it around — you’ll have Valorant . That’s a definite oversimplification, but hey, it’s definitely not a lie. That’s what you’re getting on the tin.

Valorant is a competitive tactical shooter with heavy hero shooter elements — there are quite a few different game modes, but it typically boils down to a 5-on-5 with teams alternating attack and defense. It’s a familiar format for any Counter-Strike veteran, but the focus on high-octane mobility and character abilities will definitely take some getting used to.

That said, the game hosts a rabidly competitive playerbase. In addition to conventional “Competitive Matchmaking,” Valorant features a “Premier” queue and game mode specifically for players that are looking to go pro — so if you’re looking for an esports grind to get good at, this is the title to fill that void for you.

The Case Of The Golden Idol

The Case of the Golden Idol is an exceedingly clever murder mystery game that stages a series of horrible events players need to unspool bit-by-bit. The premise is simple: players are presented with an image of some ghastly event and a block of text where crucial information is missing that they need to fill in.

By poking and prodding at the image like a good detective, players start to uncover the names of people and places, as well as potential murder weapons and actions, that explain everything that transpired the day or night of the incident. It’s clever, satisfying, and its twisted world and events are so inventive, it’s impossible to put down.

Neon White

If you’re someone who is tired of FPS games frequently leaning toward the photorealistic and wish there were more that embraced a striking visual art style but still played phenomenally, have you met my friend Neon White ? Neon White is a must-play FPS game if you’re at all a fan of the genre. We know that’s a phrase that’s used a lot (we’ve probably used it ubiquitously in several entries here), but the flash and polish of Neon White makes it more than worthy to be labeled as such.

In a dizzying blend of Mirror’s Edge and Doom Eternal , Neon White pirouettes its way into the genre as a platforming shooter that has you racing as the main protagonist across levels, exterminating heaven-invading demons as you go. For each run, you must shoot all enemies as quickly as possible using the abilities at your disposal, and what follows is a dance of gunplay and traversal that makes you feel like a veritable badass.

The story (a former denizen of Hell trying to earn a spot in Heaven) is fun, and getting to hear Steve Blum’s dulcet tones is always a plus. But the cream of the crop is the gameplay, which, as we said earlier, is a must-play phenomenon.

Ryse: Son Of Rome

Though it originally surfaced as a launch title for the Xbox One some ten years ago, this fairly straightforward third-person brawler wears its age fairly admirably — though that isn’t to say that it doesn’t wear it at all. It’s definitely an Xbox One game, but it’s a solid one.

Ryse: Son of Rome slips you into the hobnailed sandals of Roman general Marius Titus, and… well, without spoiling too much, proceeds to unspool a plot more than vaguely reminiscent of the Y2K film Gladiator . In terms of story, it does the job, but it’s far from the game’s selling point — the meaty, visceral, highly stylized combat.

On the tin, it’s a simple enough affair of timed prompts and quick-time events. It never gets too complex, but will certainly offer a challenge and manages to provide some depth with a series of unlockable “perks” that provide different bonuses upon defeating enemies.

The real kicker, however, is the sheer amount of visual flair that it manages to pack in and the fluidity with which it implements its systems into the visual effects. If you missed this one upon the Xbox One’s 2013 launch, it’s well worth the seven or eight hour spin to beat.

Nickelodeon All-Star Brawl 2

It’s not often that a game comes close to matching the arena brawl perfection that is Super Smash Bros. Ultimate ; that title has long been the bar that similar games strive to reach. Quite honestly, the first Nickelodeon All-Star Brawl was an absolute failure and didn’t come within miles of that standard. However, with this second entry, the unbelievable has occurred: we’ve gotten a brawler that feels unique, has fantastic, nostalgia-driven fighters, and comes leagues closer to that Smash Bros. mark.

There is twice the polish here than there was before, and the inclusion of Slime-fueled ultimate attacks lends the game an extra bit of identity. And being frank once again, it’s just freakin’ cool to be Squidward slapping the heck out of Jimmy Neutron. We grew up on these cartoons, so getting the chance to play as them with such a silly fun concept is a blast. Plus, there aren’t many fighting games available on Xbox Game Pass, so this makes for a great addition to the library.

Still Wakes The Deep

The walking-simulator style of horror games we’ve gotten in recent years have been superb. And one of the most exemplary titles of this genre is Still Wakes the Deep . This game places you in one of the most unique settings we’ve been to in a video game, and a ripe one for scare potential. You play as Caz, an electrician aboard the Beira, an oil rig way out in the North Sea. Everyone working on the rig is pretty much isolated from the rest of the world save for some shoddy radio equipment, aged lifeboats, and one lone chopper.

This isolation, as you could probably guess, comes into play when the workers drill into something they should not have drilled into. As Caz, you have to navigate the crumbling rig and bypass these otherworldly horrors that begin enmeshing themselves within the infrastructure of the rig and your human coworkers. The performances in Still Wakes the Deep are absolutely phenomenal. No fake screaming here. As the people begin undergoing grotesque transformations, their howls, moans, and shrieks all feel terrifyingly legitimate.

And while the minimal gameplay is not going to win any awards, it’s an enjoyable, albeit spine-tingling walk through what it would feel like if a Cthulhu-inspired infection/monstrosity broke out in your place of work.

Have A Nice Death

Work yourself to death. Or, well, a little ways past it. That’s the gist of Have A Nice Death . This slick little roguelike puts you into the tattered robes of an adorably stylized Grim Reaper — or Death — and tasks you with getting the whole business of the afterlife back on track. And it is very much a business, these days. Things have gone a bit wonky with Death Inc. and you, as the CEO, have a moral obligation to fix it with some… relatively aggressive micromanagement.

Which, naturally, entails taking up your scythe, spells, and a host of other potent tools and hacking, blasting, and platforming your way through disgruntled minions to get to the bottom of Death Inc’s management woes. The action’s pretty fast-paced — you’ll need to coordinate your dashing, jumping, and various attacks pretty effectively to make meaningful progress, but it’s pretty easy to get the hang of once you’re into the swing of things.

Most of the game’s trappings aren’t reinventing the wheel. You have limited (but replenishable) heals a la Dark Souls , you’ll map your powers and equipment to a precious few limited slots, and spend currency on upgrades between deaths or at the occasional shop along the way. But where Have A Nice Death shines is in the tight gameplay elements, cutesy aesthetics, and naturally, the humor born of a corporatized afterlife. It’s bound to be particularly appealing if you loved Team Cherry’s Hollow Knight , so give it a swing.

The Callisto Protocol

Many were disappointed with The Callisto Protocol when it first launched as they were expecting a direct analog to Dead Space given that developer Striking Distance Studios’ Glen Schofield, one of the original co-creators of Isaac Clarke’s first adventure aboard the Ishimura, was behind the game. However, when you begin your first forays with Callisto , it’s clear that while some inspiration for the setting and monsters are apparent, the gameplay and principle behind combat is wildly different.

You play as Jacob Lee, a man wrongfully imprisoned on the moon of Callisto at the worst possible time. An outbreak of something is turning the inmates into monsters, and you play as Jacob as he struggles to make his way out of Black Iron Prison. An intriguing premise, and when you first get control of Jacob’s movements, there’s this feeling that it’ll be just like walking in Isaac Clarke’s shoes once again. However, combat is a more measured affair, relying on timed swings with your melee weapon, dodging swipes from hideous monsters, and conserving ammo for when you encounter larger monstrosities. The fighting is more restrained, and the journey itself is far more linear.

Despite these differences, The Callisto Protocol is a more enjoyable horror romp than people give it credit for. The tension as you trudge through dilapidated prison corridors is vivid, and the visuals are nothing short of breathtaking despite the horrific surroundings. Both its linear nature and inclusion on Xbox Game Pass’ library lend added weight to the game’s approachable nature. So if you’re looking for another horror offering, Callisto Protocol is the perfect game for you.

Octopath Traveler

You might take one look at Octopath Traveler’s cover art, skim over a few screenshots, and assume that it’s nostalgia bait — a plainly-written love letter to JRPG enthusiasts stricken with the notion that it never got better than ATB battles rendered in 16-bit graphics. And really, you wouldn’t be entirely wrong. But you’d be doing yourself a significant disservice if you assumed that was the entirety of what this game is putting on the table.

Octopath Traveler wears its nostalgia trap on its pixellated sleeves, that’s true. But it wraps that core in several layers of modernized goodness that truly make it pop. Firstly, the entirety of the game is rendered in an initially disorienting (and eventually charming) 2D/3D design direction, with 2D sprites for characters interacting in 3D environments. It also sprinkles in a few decidedly “modern” graphical effects — just-modern-enough to give its mid-90’s aesthetic a modern sheen.

Upon getting started, the game immediately confronts you with eight overlapping character stories to choose from (each character resembling a different JRPG class trope, naturally), each with its own arc and satisfying conclusion. That said, having eight distinct character arcs to work through can be a bit time-intensive — but hey, those of us used to four-disc PS1 epics shouldn’t really find that to be an issue.

Another Crab’s Treasure

Xbox Game Pass has been really on top of adding fantastic games to its collection these past few weeks (and for you reading, we mean at the time of writing this updated entry). So many titles have been added, it’s been tough playing them all in a timely fashion to keep up with including the best ones here. Which is why we’re a bit late to add Another Crab’s Treasure to our list.

You play as a small hermit crab who gets their shell “repossessed” by a Loan Shark (a talking shark head; it’s hilarious) on behalf of the Duchess of Slacktide. And thus begins your journey to reclaim your shell, find out what is going on in this deteriorating ocean land, and battle a heck ton of bosses.

To put it simply, Another Crab’s Treasure is a Soulslike with a cute visual style and a whopping amount of humor. When we first picked it up, we were not expecting it to be as charming as it was. But the heart of the game and its fairly deep yet still approachable mechanics make it a fantastic Soulslike game to try.

Harold Halibut

Before even thinking about installing Harold Halibut , you should know exactly what kind of game you’re getting into. Harold Halibut is a glacially-paced, narrative-driven title that, on the surface, doesn’t say much. You’re following along the amiable yet bland Harold aboard the Fedora, an underwater ship that has been marooned on a watery planet for years.

This station is full of quirky characters you can talk to and assist throughout the game’s runtime. And while there are a handful of fascinating gameplay moments sprinkled throughout, you’re largely just side-scroll-ambling down corridors to start mild conversations with these people.

This all may sound like harsh critiques against the game, but Harold Halibut’s status as a hidden gem is enshrined between two pillars: its unique visual style and the unrelenting adherence to the themes it's going for. The handmade, stop-motion techniques on display are both delightful and impressive. There is no other game that looks like Harold Halibut .

Similarly, there is no other game that is about what Harold Halibut is about. (I’m not going to spoil the plot.) So while there is a possibility you will play through the game and find it resoundingly boring, there is also a chance that the themes it’s trying to convey will just solidly land for you. And if they do land, they will land hard.

Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons

Have you ever wanted to know what Josef Fares was up to before he worked on A Way Out and It Takes Two ? Prior to those amazing, cooperative-driven titles, Fares worked on a small but ambitious single-player puzzle game called Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons . And to our delight, it’s been added to the Xbox Game Pass library. Even though this game is meant to be played by one person, you can feel the seeds of “cooperation DNA” in its bones.

Each brother is controlled by one half of a controller, with one toggle moving the oldest and the other moving the youngest. At first, it’ll make your brain go cross-eyed as you acquaint yourself with this disjointed style of control, but as you stick with the boys’ journey to save their father, climbing mountains, causing diversions, and dodging enemies, it feels more natural.

As with many of Fares’ games, Brothers doesn’t overstay its welcome, with each section of the adventure lasting as long as it needs to before moving on to the next thing. And by the time the conclusion rolls around, you’ll find that this may be one of Fares’ most emotionally satisfying narratives yet.

Tomb Raider

The Tomb Raider series has a whole host of fantastic games in its history, from the iconic title that started it all to the much-beloved Tomb Raider: Legend . And though we often see reboots that don’t do the original justice in the video game world, thankfully, Crystal Dynamics did not let us down with the beginning of its Survivor trilogy.

In this outing, Lara Croft isn’t the seasoned raider of tombs we’ve known for years, but rather an inexperienced explorer thrust into an incredibly dangerous adventure that will have her clinging to life (and a lot of cliff sides) more often than not. This rebooted Tomb Raider has you guiding Lara through some of the most harrowing situations you will ever see in a game. Not only does she have to unravel a perilous mystery at the heart of a lost island’s cult, she has to deal with armed thugs and terrifyingly sharp river debris.

I kid you not, if you thought Lara Croft was a light-hearted adventure with a bit of “archaeology” thrown in, this Survivor reboot will catch you unprepared. Near the very beginning of the game, Lara needs to crawl through a literal tunnel of blood after she and her team crash-land on the island. It’s gritty, but fun, action-packed with a light sprinkling of puzzles, and a joy to run a completionist playthrough on. And while it might feel wildly different from classic Tomb Raider , as you play it, you can feel the love and respect it has for what came before.

Star Wars Jedi: Survivor

The Star Wars universe, despite how oversaturated it may become with films, TV series, and games, is one that’s always ripe for new stories. One of the standout Star Wars narratives of the past decade was Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order, Respawn Entertainment’s adventure game that follows Cal Kestis, a Jedi Padawan who escaped the massacre of Order 66. That was a fantastic game in its own right, but its sequel, Star Wars Jedi: Survivor , doubles down on those narrative chops.

The gameplay largely remains the same, with a Souls-lite style of lightsaber combat, platform puzzling, and open-world-ish exploration. But the story is seriously where Survivor shines. It’s not the typical galaxy-ending conflict that we’ve seen in this franchise before, but it’s got high emotional stakes that will keep any fan of the first game gripping their controller long into the night.

Cal has to confront some ideological differences between himself and others who, while still fighting against the Empire, aren’t exactly aligning with what he views to be the right course. And, as the story proves, surviving and keeping ideologies intact don’t always go hand in hand.

Fallout 76

Fallout 76 is probably the single most divisive point of contention for a lot of dedicated fans of the franchise — and deservedly so. At launch, the game’s many shortcomings, bugs, and awkwardly executed design choices were derided pretty heavily. With that said, it did establish one significant pillar for Bethesda to build upon: it created what was, for most intents and purposes, a multiplayer Fallout experience.

In the years since its unceremonious 2018 launch, the developers have had a lot of time to reflect, adapt, and course-correct — and all that tinkering has manifested in one of those from-the-ashes stories so rarely witnessed in today’s terminally online gaming ecosystem. In its current state, Fallout 76 is a pretty decent game, and a perfectly reasonable answer to the question, “What if Fallout 4 were kind-of an MMO?”

Now that we’ve spent entirely too much time on the preamble, the premise of the game is essentially summarized in the preceding paragraph. If you’ve played Fallout 4 , then a lot of Fallout 76’s bones will be familiar to you. Largely taking place in the Appalachian region of West Virginia, Fallout 76 sees your custom-made character emerge from the depths of Fallout 76 on “Reclamation Day” alongside your fellow Vault Dwellers and try to bring some semblance of civilization to the surface world while surviving its nuclear-ravaged wilderness.

It’s a solid translation of the Fallout formula into a multiplayer format, complete with quests, NPCs, a number of factions both familiar and foreign, and that signature wasteland weirdness that makes the setting so special to begin with.

Botany Manor

If you’re looking for a relaxed, contemplative experience with just a dash of puzzle-solving, then it’s definitely worth stopping in to Botany Manor for a visit. Taking the role of Arabella Greene, you’re tasked with carrying out a bit of botany research in and around — you guessed it — the eponymous Botany Manor.

Progressing through this surprisingly vibrant and colorful 19th-century estate is accomplished by way of researching and growing various fantastical flora. You’ll collect various clues for creating each flower’s ideal growing conditions, note them in a journal, and solve thoughtful, fun little puzzles to get them blooming. All the while, you can observe various bits and baubles fleshing out the life and times of Arabella.

Altogether, it’s a peaceful, walking-simulator-esque experience that’s perfect for a quiet and cozy evening at home.

Superhot: Mind Control Delete

The slogan of “Time only moves when you do” doesn’t quite convey the sheer awesomeness that is Superhot . The game’s simplistic geometric designs and sparsely colored environments belie its true nature. Superhot is a game that captures the complexity of a puzzle game with the straightforwardness of a first-person shooter. You are placed in various scenarios where armed opponents rush your position to attack you. Your objective? Eliminate your enemies. The catch? Well, you’ve read the slogan.

Though you might expect Superhot to just be a run-and-gun, point-and-shoot type of game, it’s actually fairly cerebral. When you are moving, things occur in real-time, and dodging a bullet in real time is difficult to say the least. It’s important to remain in position for a bit to take stock of your surroundings and figure out what your next move should be. People have called Superhot “innovative” more times than we can count, and though it has become a bit of a meme at this point, there is no denying this indie title’s creativity.

Diablo IV

Despite the grim and bloody atmosphere of Diablo IV , playing through the game is actually enjoyable and entertaining. With the trademark dungeon-crawling and ARPG looting that the Diablo series is known for, this fourth installment doubles down on the amount of activities that you can get up to and lose yourself in for hours. The grinding on offer in Diablo IV is astounding. You can spend your time exploring the entire map, diving into every dungeon, creating every class of character and experimenting with builds, or just beelining toward the main narrative.

In this title, your character has to contend with Lilith, the Daughter of Hatred, as she tries to “help” humanity against the forces of Hell. Unfortunately for humanity, her help consists of disturbing rituals, allying with some Lesser Evils, and ultimately a lot of death. So in addition to a lot of content to occupy yourself with, Diablo IV has a pretty gripping narrative too. And you can play the whole thing in both online and local co-op.

item.title: The First Descendant's Season 1 Roadmap is a Good Omen
item.description:
Highlights

  • The First Descendant had a strong start but saw a drop in player numbers, with Season One update coming soon.
  • Open communication from Nexon about future updates and bug fixes is key to the game's success and player retention.
  • Season One and Season Two updates will bring new content like Descendants, Colossus, weapons, and skins to keep players engaged.

Nexon Games’ The First Descendant got off to a strong start when it first launched in early July 2024, reaching major player count milestones despite the technical difficulties that the game initially faced. Player numbers have slowly dwindled since then, but future updates for The First Descendant already look promising, so this could turn around very soon.

The First Descendant ’s Season One update is set to be released soon in late August 2024. From what’s been revealed about this new Season, fans of the game already have a good idea of what to expect from this major update for the game. In hindsight, Nexon Games’ open communication about The First Descendant ’s upcoming live-service updates so far could prove to be one of the game’s keys to success over time.

Why Communication Is Key For The First Descendant’s Future Updates

According to Steam Charts, player numbers have dropped to around a quarter of The First Descendant ’s peak player count on Steam just one month after the game’s massively successful launch. However, with the first Seasonal update just around the corner, plenty of players across all platforms will likely return to the game, and Nexon’s open communication about The First Descendant ’s upcoming content will likely be a big factor in the popularity of the game’s future updates.

What to Expect From The First Descendant’s Season One and Season Two Updates

Season One Episode: Invasion Season Two Episode: Ancestor
  • Release date: late August 2024
  • Season Progression
  • Field Completion
  • New Descendant and Descendant Story
  • New Ultimate Descendant
  • New Colossus/Dungeon
  • New Weapon
  • New Skin
  • Release date: early December 2024
  • Season Progression
  • New Mega Dungeon
  • Utility Companion
  • New Descendant and Descendant Story
  • New Ultimate Descendant
  • New Colossus/Dungeon
  • New Weapon
  • New Skin

Clear Communication Will Help The First Descendant's Future Updates Thrive

Aside from knowing what kind of content to expect, knowing the start and end date of Seasonal content updates is also crucial for live-service games like The First Descendant . In the case of The First Descendant , knowing the length of current and upcoming Seasons will help players pace their progress in the Seasonal battle pass to not miss out on any limited-time exclusive rewards. So, with the general schedule of the next two Seasons already communicated well ahead of their release dates, players should have plenty of time to gauge their progress to get everything done before a given Season ends.

Even outside of The First Descendant ’s seasonal content roadmap, open communication about bug fixes and other known issues with the game will also go a long way toward keeping the game alive and well between major content updates. So far, Nexon Games has also been on top of this, keeping an up-to-date monthly log detailing The First Descendant ’s known issues, including ones that are actively under investigation and those that have been fixed. Considering that the game faced many technical issues in its first week after release, open communication like this should provide plenty of reassurance if the game faces any new issues in the future.

As early as one month into the game’s post-launch lifecycle it’s already apparent that Nexon Games is actively seeking player feedback while also keeping players well-informed on what’s to come to the game. At the moment, Nexon has already revealed general details of what’s to come in the game’s first two Seasonal updates for The First Descendant , giving players a preview of what to expect from the game several months in advance. With this kind of transparency about major content updates as well as minor bug fixes, Nexon Games keeping an open line of communication with the game’s playerbase going forward should be a sweet treat for both new and returning fans of The First Descendant that will help the game thrive.

item.title: The First Descendant: How To Farm Murky Energy Residue
item.description:
Quick Links

  • What Is Murky Energy Residue In The First Descendant?
  • Where To Farm Murky Energy Residue?

There are various types of crafting materials that you can loot in The First Descendant . These materials can be used to unlock weapons, characters and much more, making them a crucial aspect of this game. Among them, one very important crafting material is the Murky Energy Residue.

If you're planning on unlocking Descendants like Valby or researching Crystallization Catalysts, then you'll need lots of this energy residue. But you can't find this material everywhere. Rather, it can only be farmed at certain locations. So, to help you with that, here's how to farm Murky Energy Residue in The First Descendant .

What Is Murky Energy Residue In The First Descendant?

Murky Energy Residue is an essential crafting material in The First Descendant , essential for leveling up characters and crafting key items like Crystallization Catalysts . These catalysts are vital for assigning socket types to Weapon and Descendant Modules, making Murky Energy Residue a must-have resource if you want to enhance your gear without spending real money.

Farming this material is also necessary for characters like Valby. Here's a breakdown of the research recipes that require Murky Energy Residue:

Item

Materials Needed

Valby Stabilizer

246 Monad Shard, 249 Compound Coating Material, 40 Murky Energy Residue, 1 Valby Stabilizer Blueprint

Crystallization Catalyst

8 Murky Energy Residue, 22 Macromolecule Biogel, 8 Mixed Energy Residue, 18 Advanced Neural Circuit

Where To Farm Murky Energy Residue?

Murky Energy Residue can be farmed in only two missions in the Sterile Lands Region of The First Descendant . Here are both of the locations, and how much energy residue you can expect to get from clearing these missions:

  1. The Forgottense (Restricted Zone, Sterile Land): Located in the southeast corner of Sterile Land, this mission is one of the top spots for farming Murky Energy Residue. You'll encounter multiple Elite Vulgus enemies that drop up to 15 Murky Energy Residues per run . The Forgottense is a quick and efficient farming location, especially when you're using a Descendant like Bunny.
  2. Unknown Laboratory (Classified Area, Sterile Land): This is another mission in the northwest corner of Sterile Land, that has a similar yield of Murky Energy Residue as The Forgottense. Here, you’ll encounter Vulguses that can drop around 10 or more residues per run.

You can use fast travel between Unknown Laboratory and The Forgottense to maximize your farming efficiency, letting you farm up to 25-40 Murky Energy Residue in a complete run.
